predictions.prediction: Seal of Ur-nigar

metadata.notes: kišib (KICIB) means "seal" or "sealed document". Ur-nigar is a personal name, common in Ur III period texts. The name follows the typical Sumerian naming pattern of "Ur-" (servant of) + deity or concept.

"sar" is a Sumerian surface area unit (approximately 36 square meters). "NUMB" likely represents a number that was not fully transliterated from the original cuneiform tablet.

predictions.reference: year : “ The silver-chair of Enlil was fashioned . ”
predictions.prediction: Year (in which) the throne of Enlil was fashioned

metadata.translation: Year (in which) the throne of Enlil was fashioned

predictions.reference: booked out of ( the account of ) Ahuni ,
predictions.prediction: withdrawn from Ahuni

metadata.translation: withdrawn from Ahuni
metadata.notes: This is a common administrative formula in Ur III period texts. "ki" means "place/from", "Ahuni" is a personal name (with the genitive suffix -ta meaning "from"), and "ba-zi" means "was withdrawn/disbursed". This phrase typically indicates that goods or commodities were disbursed from the account or custody of a person named Ahuni.

metadata.notes: The term "u" represents the numeral 10 in Sumerian. "mucbian" (also written muš-bi-an) refers to rushes or reeds used for roofing purposes. This is likely an administrative notation recording building materials.

predictions.prediction: from Budu (the place of Budu)

metadata.translation: from Budu (the place of Budu)
metadata.notes: The term "ki" means "place" or is used as a locative marker meaning "from" when used with personal names or place names. "Budu" appears to be a personal name or place name. In Ur III administrative texts, "ki PN-ta" is a common formula meaning "from (the place/account of) PN" indicating the source of goods or transactions.

'šu-nigin' (cunigin) means "total/grand total", GAN is a unit of land area measurement, 'guruš' (guruc) refers to able-bodied male workers/young men, and 'ugula' means overseer/foreman. The number (NUMB) is a placeholder for the actual numerical value in the original tablet.

predictions.prediction: Gilgamesh

metadata.translation: Gilgamesh
metadata.notes: This is the Sumerian spelling of the name of the legendary king of Uruk, hero of the famous Epic of Gilgamesh. The name is sometimes interpreted as meaning "the old man is a young man" or "the ancestor is a hero" (from Sumerian bilga-mes). Gilgamesh was a semi-mythical ruler traditionally dated to around 2700-2600 BCE.

NUMB likely represents a number that was not fully transcribed in the transliteration.

"cagadu" (also written šagadu) refers to a type of garment or textile. "sumun" means "old" or "worn." The "NUMB" likely represents a number that should precede the counted items. This is typical of Ur III period administrative texts recording textile inventories.

metadata.notes: This appears to be a brief administrative notation. "Tir-ula" is likely a personal name, and "dab" (here written as "idab" with the verbal prefix i-) means "to seize, take, hold." This type of phrase is common in Ur III administrative texts indicating that a named individual took responsibility for or received something (the object would typically be mentioned in the preceding context).

This is a common administrative formula in Ur III texts indicating the official who conveyed or was responsible for a transaction.

"gaz" means "crushed" or "pounded," indicating processed sesame, likely for oil extraction or culinary use. This type of entry is common in Ur III period commodity records.

predictions.reference: year after : “ The house Puzris-Dagan was erected . ”
predictions.prediction: Year following (the year) the temple of Puzriš-Dagan was built

metadata.translation: Year following (the year) the temple of Puzriš-Dagan was built
metadata.notes: This is a Sumerian year name formula (mu-formula) from the Ur III period. "mu us₂-sa" means "year following," "e₂" means "temple/house," "puzuriš-dagan" is a place name (also known as Drehem), and "ba-du₃" means "was built." These year names were used to date administrative documents in ancient Mesopotamia.

predictions.prediction: And Lugalbaba, son of Urlamma

metadata.translation: And Lugalbaba, son of Urlamma
metadata.notes: This is a typical Sumerian personal name formula. "u" functions as a conjunction ("and"), "lugalbaba" is a personal name (meaning "Lugal is [my] father"), "dumu" means "son/child of", and "urlamma" is the father's name (a theophoric name referencing the goddess Lamma). This format is commonly found in administrative texts from the Ur III period.

predictions.prediction: X mana (and) X shekels of silver

metadata.translation: X mana (and) X shekels of silver
metadata.notes: This is a standard Ur III weight/value notation. "mana" is a unit of weight (approximately 500 grams), "gin" is a smaller unit (1/60 of a mana, approximately 8.3 grams), and "ku" (kù-babbar or kù) refers to silver. The actual numerical values (NUMB) were not provided in the transliteration, so they are represented as X. This type of phrase commonly appears in administrative and economic texts recording quantities of precious metals.

predictions.reference: year : “ the lord of Enki was hired . ”
predictions.prediction: Year (when) the en-priest of Enki was installed

metadata.translation: Year (when) the en-priest of Enki was installed
metadata.notes: This is a year-name formula (mu-formula) from the Ur III period. "mu" = year, "en" = en-priest (high priest/priestess), "enki" = the god Enki (god of wisdom and fresh waters), "ba-hun" = was installed/appointed (passive voice). Year-names were used to date administrative documents by significant events, in this case the installation of a high priest of the god Enki.
